themes.label: Inventories
themes.rationale: The inscription provides a detailed list of sacred objects, including silver bowls, cups, and a gold crown, along with their specific weights, which is characteristic of a temple inventory.
themes.quote: φι λαι ργυρα 0 σταθμ ν το[ τ]ον ττηηηηδδδ κ[ ρατ]α [ ργυρ 0 σταθμ ν το τον]

themes.label: Accounts and Financial Records
themes.rationale: The text records the formal transfer of sacred property (chremata) from one board of treasurers to their successors, a standard financial administrative procedure in Athens.
themes.quote: ταμ αι τον ερον χρεμ[ τον] τες θενα ας ... παρ δοσαν το ς ταμ αις

themes.label: Lists of Officials or Citizens
themes.rationale: The inscription names several Athenian officials, including the treasurers (tamiai) and the secretaries (grammateis) of the board, identifying them by name, patronymic, and deme.
themes.quote: πολυχσεν δες χαρνε ς κα χσυν ρχοντες ... γραμμ τευε

themes.label: Votive Dedications
themes.rationale: The items listed, such as the gold crown and silver vessels, are dedicated to the goddess Athena and kept in her sanctuary as sacred property.
themes.quote: ταμ αι τον ερον χρεμ τον τες θενα ας

themes.label: Stele
themes.rationale: The stoichedon layout and the nature of the Athenian financial record indicate this was inscribed on a stone stele.
themes.quote: [τ δε ι] ταμ αι τον ερον χρεμ[ τον]

themes.label: Marble
themes.rationale: Official Athenian administrative records of the 5th century BCE were typically inscribed on marble.
themes.quote: [τ δε ι] ταμ αι τον ερον χρεμ[ τον]

themes.label: Fragmentary
themes.rationale: The presence of numerous brackets in the transcription indicates that significant portions of the text are missing and have been reconstructed.
themes.quote: [τ δε ι] ταμ αι τον ερον χρεμ[ τον]

persons.name: Leukaios son of Komarchos of Aphidna
Autokleides son of Sostratos of Phrearrhioi
Polymedes son of Kephisophon of Atene

rationale: This inscription is an Athenian temple inventory from the late 5th century BCE, specifically recording the transfer (paradosis) of sacred treasures of Athena between outgoing and incoming boards of treasurers (tamiai). It lists various precious metal objects, primarily silver phialai and cups, along with a gold crown, noting their weights in the Attic acrophonic numeral system. The text identifies officials by name, patronymic, and deme, following the standard administrative practices of the period.
